subject: OS-7182 vmadm can create/destroy/rollback bhyve VM snapshots Reviewed by: Mike Gerdts <mike.gerdts@joyent.com> Reviewed by: Pedro Palazón Candel <pedro@joyent.com> Approved by: Josh Wilsdon <josh@wilsdon.ca> Approved by: Pedro Palazón Candel <pedro@joyent

Patch Set 9: -Code-Review

Pulled +1 after reconsidering mounting of bhyve snapshots.  Since the mounts under <zoneroot>/checkpoints/ could only ever be read by the bhyve process and it would never do that, we shouldn't even mount the snapshots for bhyve.  More verbosely: https://chat.joyent.us/joyent/pl/kbgnfqqnpfgpzj53ei1qy55zco

Patch Set 10: Code-Review+1

Code looks good to me, waiting on tests results for IA+1.

Btw, and this is not related to this issue, since Dylan is following an already stablished pattern, is there any reason we're systematically not adding any name to the functions invoked by pipelines, for example?. Apart of a good way of documenting the intention of such functions, it's definitely helpful when debugging issues.

As far as I know, there isn't a rule to enforce such names for JSLint, but here is the same rule for ESLint with some explanation regarding recommended usage: https://eslint.org/docs/rules/func-names

Generic question: Is it possible to optionally exclude a disk from the snapshot? Say a bhyve vm with 2 disks, one is OS one is DATA, so only the OS gets rolled back? 

From what I can tell, currently that is a no. But maybe worth a follow-up somewhere down the road.

Patch Set 14: Code-Review+1 Integration-Approval+1
Change has been successfully merged by Dylan Yep
In the case of bhyve we have datasets other than the zoneroot dataset, since we have the disks. Perhaps "or any datasets other than the zoneroot dataset and its dependent datasets?"
Done
For bhyve we're restoring the disks too, right? Not just the root dataset.
Yes. Changed wording to make that clear.
Is there value in duplicating this here when this has already been done at L11528?
+1 on this.
Done
the indentation here I found confusing (might just be gerrit)
Done
I concur with Josh regarding indentation. I'd prefer to have some indentation here even at the cost that we're also closing the parentheses with that extra indentation. More clear, IMO
Done
And the same indentation thing
Done
Geez! these options should be documented somewhere!
nice catch!

The common case I believe with bhyve is still 2 disks. So it might be good to test with such a configuration. To ensure that both disks get snapshotted and rolled back.

Ideally I think we'd come up with some way to verify that the data on both volumes was rolled back. The only way I can think to do that though is with a user-script and mdata-put. Even just having a user-script that wrote to a file on each volume (changing on each boot if the file exists), after doing an mdata-put of those values... Then the test could reboot, to ensure the value changed, then rollback to ensure the old value was returned.

Maybe that's overkill here though? I don't know.
Done
Not needed.  The statechange file in illumos-joyent should be modified instead.
Done
This file already exists in the illumos-joyent repo as usr/src/lib/brand/bhyve/zone/statechange
I'll open an illumos-joyent PR shortly

regexp is unnecessarily expensive.  The following should work at a lower cost.

return snapshot.split("@vmsnap-")[1] === snapname
Done
why not do the check closer to where we check for kvm?  Same goes for the other similar changes in this round.

I think the reason (Dylan correct me if I'm wrong) is that we're adding support here for bhyve snapshots. But the checks for KVM are all about rejecting the command altogether. 

Here we're just skipping the umount and the rmdir and the other mucking around inside the VM's datasets from the GZ. Which we can't do for bhyve.
Yeah, got it.  I misread this.

This sync is happening in the guest and does not necessarily cause a sync(2).  At best, it is calling fsync(2) on the zvols that have the guest's disk(s).  This could cause a change in timing that results int more success.

Critically, it does not call vfs_sync on zones/$uuid or fsync on /zones/$uuid/config/metadata.json.

The test failures you described could be attributed to:

1. Old data in metadata.js: directory content not cached after rename()

2. Empty metadata.js:  writes were reordered. rename() made it to disk but the write to metadata.js.new was not written to disk.

3. No metadata.js: I don't have an explanation for this, if a write related to a rename() fails, it should give you the old or the new file - losing it is not POSIX compliant.

Maybe a proper fix for the underlying problem is better.  In VM.js, writeAndRename() should open the temp file, write data to it, then:

fs.fsync(tmpfilefd)
fs.rename()
fs.open(dirname, "r")
fs.fsync(dirfd)
fs.close(dirfd)


One thing that a proper fix must not do is call sync(1) or sync(2).  That will cause all cached data for all file systems to be written out.  That can be very expensive to do at the rate that can be induced by mdata-put.
Dylan clarified by chat that the files that were not correct were the guest files.  Thus, the sync in the guest is correct.
I suspect that this can be set down to about 15350 (or even a bit smaller if disks[1] is shrunk to 512), which may help it pass on CoaL when there's already another VM and a few images present.
Done
